Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Interactions between Indoor and Atmospheric Chemistry. France, Mid-May 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1518848
Morrison

The objective of this workshop is to outline a research plan to effectively and efficiently improve the understanding of indoor air chemistry. The science of indoor air chemistry is several decades old, but remains in its infancy. The much more mature science of atmospheric (outdoor) chemistry can be leveraged to rapidly advance knowledge in the indoor environment.

This workshop will result in the first of its kind: a focused collaboration of international outdoor and indoor scientists and engineers with a resulting plan of action for research on indoor chemistry. This workshop brings together 50 atmospheric and indoor air chemistry researchers to present and discuss contemporary research in both fields, pose and answer key research questions and define future indoor air chemistry research objectives. A primary outcome of the 2-day workshop will be one or more documents outlining the major questions, research objectives and research solutions that are identified during workshop sessions. Where possible, these documents will be turned into publishable manuscripts in the form of regular journal articles or editorials. The PIs anticipate that the workshop will set the stage for future workshops and that the outcomes of this workshop will help define the direction of indoor chemistry research in the near future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On July 2nd 2016, the second Interactions Between Indoor and Atmospheric Chemistry workshopwas held in Ghent, Belgium at the University of Ghent. This workshop, supported by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and the National Science Foundation, brought together 35 atmospheric and indoor air chemistry researchers to present and discuss contemporary research in both fields, pose and answer key research questions and define future indoor air chemistry research objectives. One of the main objectives of this workshop was to develop a list of questions, barriers and opportunities that would help guide short-term and long-term research in the area of indoor chemistry and shared indoor/atmospheric topics, approaches and tools, with a focus on multiphase processes and their impact on indoor environments and occupants.

In 3 technical sessions, speakers discussed the similarities and differences between the chemistry taking place in buildings and in the atmosphere. The sessions focused on experimental studies on multiphase chemistry, the impact of multiphase processes on human exposure and the characterization of surfaces and multiphase processes.

Presenters discussed the latest investigations into surface chemistry including observations that cleaning with bleach can result in interesting chlorine chemistry, surface interactions can significantly influence air concentrations of pollutants but also influence the growth and composition of aerosols, photosensitization reactions of surface organic acids, semi-volatile organic compounds can sorb to clothing and influence dermal uptake. Water in aerosols has been shown to influence reaction rates and oligomerization but may also be important in understanding the epidemiology of aerosols. Models of multiphase chemistry in aerosols were extended to understand ozone reactions at human skin surfaces and size-resolved measurements of persistent organic pollutants points to multiple pathways from source to particle. The challenge of understanding the very-wide variety of building surfaces, locations, history and conditions was discussed as well as the potential of contemporary instrumentation and large-scale field chambers or buildings to advance the field.

During break-out discussion, several key questions and recommendations for future research were identified. Multiphase chemistry and composition of indoor interfaces remain a major unknown. The composition of surface coatings and the nature of underlying substrates (e.g. carpet or paint) need much attention as do the mechanisms that control the aging of surfaces and development of surface films. The extremely diverse nature of indoor environments and microenvironments makes this effort challenging, especially considering the impact that occupant and their activities have. A focus on major material types and a better understanding of the impact of occupants and their activities may help overcome the diversity challenge. Participants suggested that portfolio of tools and approaches will be necessary to make progress. Laboratory based measurements and modeling studies can help develop large-scale, but carefully controlled, chamber experiments which can be extended to better understand field site measurements. Field site measurements provide opportunities for discovery of novel species and phenomena that can be explored in a more controlled way in the laboratory. Throughout this process, the observations and discoveries in atmospheric chemistry should continue to inform indoor studies; better still will be collaborations between scientists and engineers that study atmospheric processes and those studying building environments.

Intellectual Merit: This workshop was a focused collaboration of international outdoor and indoor scientists and engineers with a resulting plan of action for research on indoor chemistry. By bringing together the top scholars, we evaluated existing research and generate new ideas. This process acted as a selective filter, refocusing our attention on the most productive path.

Broader Impact: By advancing indoor air research, we more rapidly and efficiently identify key causes of indoor exposure to toxic species. In doing so, we provide tangible strategies and technologies for enhancing public health by improving indoor air quality. Several early-career faculty participated in the workshop.
